ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR:OTH 37739 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
  
 
 
FOR  
 
 
STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF FINANCIAL SECTOR 
 
REGULATORS AND SUPERVISORS 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
 
 
     
   
       
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  APEC  –  Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FRTI  –  Financial Regulators' Training Program 
  FSAP  –  Financial Sector Assessment Program 
  INPRS  –  International Network of Pension Regulators and Supervisors 
  OECD  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development  
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by H. Feig, Finance and Infrastructure Division,  
Regional and Sustainable Development Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   Lack of adequate financial sector regulation and supervision was one of the major 
causes of the Asian financial crisis. In addition to policy and governance issues, inadequate 
capacity of banking supervisors and securities regulators was identified as a key constraint to 
implementing the best international practices in financial sector regulation and supervision in 
many of the affected countries.  In response, finance ministers of member economies1 of the 
Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) endorsed the establishment of the APEC Financial 
Regulators'  Training  Initiative  (FRTI)  in  May  1998  to  enhance  training  efforts  for  financial 
regulators at national and regional (i.e., within Asia) levels. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has been acting as secretariat to the FRTI and has financially supported its training activities 
under various technical assistance projects (TA).2 Considering progress achieved under the 
FRTI and the continued need for training in this area, APEC finance ministers, in September 
2003, extended the FRTI for a third time and requested a continuation of ADB’s role. ADB has 
also been approached for support by other regional cooperation initiatives in the financial sector, 
including for pension regulators. Such cooperation is expected to contribute to a harmonization 
of standards and practices in financial sector regulation and supervision across the region. The 
TA framework is presented in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Financial stability is crucial for sustained economic growth and cannot be achieved 
without strong financial systems. Effective financial sector supervision promotes stability by 
ensuring that financial institutions operate in a safe and sound manner.  Financial institutions 
must have adequate risk management policies and procedures and operate with sufficient 
levels of capital. Skilled supervisors are key to effective financial sector supervision. Supervisors 
must understand the risks inherent in financial activities and must be capable of assessing the 
adequacy of risk management policies, systems, and practices of financial institutions under 
their supervision. Most DMCs are committed to implementing the core principles for banking 
supervision and securities regulation developed by the Bank for International Settlements and 
the  International  Organization  of  Securities  Commissions,  respectively,  which  require  well-
trained  regulators  and  supervisors.  The  FRTI  and  other  initiatives  have  considerably 
strengthened training programs at national and regional levels after the Asian financial crisis. 
There is scope for further improving training programs for DMC financial regulators in line with 
international standards to ensure that staff actively involved in supervision and enforcement 
activities possess the necessary competencies.   
 
3.  The FRTI has had separate programs for banking supervisors and securities regulators. 
The banking supervision program receives major TA support from the United States Federal 
Reserve System. The securities regulation program has used instructors from regulatory and 
other relevant institutions in APEC member economies for its training courses. The work of the 
FRTI receives oversight through APEC advisory groups representing bank supervision and 
securities regulatory agencies from member countries and other interested parties. 
 
                                                           
1   Australia; Brunei Darussalam; Canada; Chile; People’s Republic of China (PRC); Hong Kong, China; Indonesia; 
Japan; Republic of Korea; Malaysia; Mexico; New Zealand; Papua New Guinea; Peru; Philippines; Russia; 
Singapore; Taipei,China; Thailand; United States; and Viet Nam.

2  
4.  The  FRTI  has  made  good  progress  in  achieving  its  two  original  objectives:  (i) 
strengthening  content  and  management  of  national  training  programs  and  (ii)  developing 
regional programs for junior and mid-level supervisors and regulators. The FRTI has trained 
more than 1,300 developing member country (DMC) participants (including 108 from non-APEC 
DMCs) in 19 regional and 13 national courses.  Courses in banking supervision covered bank 
analysis, credit risk analysis, market risk analysis, risk management and internal controls, and 
on-site  supervision,  with  course  content  reflecting  the  Basel  Committee's  Core  Principles. 
Courses in securities regulations focused on generic training topics that are related to market 
supervision and investigation and enforcement, and are relevant for countries at different stages 
of capital market development. In addition, seminars were held on current regulatory issues 
such as demutualization and investor education. The FRTI also developed audiovisual training 
products covering the core areas in banking supervision training (i.e., bank analysis, credit risk 
analysis, and market risk analysis), as well as a web-based self-study course for newly hired 
securities regulators.  Feedback from supervisory agencies indicates that the training programs 
have been well received by participants and that training materials developed under the FRTI 
have been used and incorporated in national training programs.  For example, FRTI's self-study 
materials are given to incoming staff of these agencies to address their immediate training 
needs until formal training courses are scheduled. 
 
5.  To sustain the achievements of the FRTI, training institutions at the regional and, more 
importantly, national level, will have to assume greater responsibility for the delivery of course 
content developed as part of this initiative. To facilitate this process, the APEC finance ministers 
recently extended the FRTI for a further year with the aim of (i) delivering additional training 
courses at the regional level to help build a critical mass of potential trainers, and (ii) organizing 
the transfer of training programs and products developed under the FRTI to training institutions 
at the national and regional levels.   
 
6.  The finance ministers also endorsed an enhanced advisory group structure, principally 
for (i) monitoring the status of financial regulators’ training in the region; (ii) reviewing the 
effectiveness of existing training programs and approaches; (iii) identifying emerging training 
needs of financial regulators and discussing new approaches to address such needs; and 
(iv) facilitating the exchange of information on training events, resources, materials, and best 
practices.   
 
7.  The  Financial  Action  Task  Force—the  organization  with  primary  responsibility  for 
developing  a  worldwide  anti-money  laundering  framework—has  made  a  number  of 
recommendations on how regulators and supervisors of financial institutions should implement 
the framework. For financial institutions subject to the Core Principles, many regulatory and 
supervisory measures that apply to prudential purposes should apply in a similar manner to anti-
money laundering and terrorist financing purposes.  Other financial institutions, including those 
in the insurance and pension sectors, that can be conduits for money-laundering activities, 
should  be  properly  licensed  and  regulated  in  line  with  national  anti-money-laundering 
requirements. While anti-money laundering legal and regulatory frameworks have recently been 
upgraded in many DMCs, supervision and enforcement capacity has lagged behind.  No training 
programs are currently available at regional or global level that address the specific training 
needs of supervisors in this area.     
 
8.  Many pensions systems in Asia, as in other regions, are being transformed from public 
pay-as-you-go into funded systems with varying degrees of private pension provision. The 
development of funded pension systems needs to be accompanied by efforts to strengthen the 
financial  market  infrastructure  and  the  establishment  of  a  modern  and  effective  regulatory

3
framework  for  private  pensions,  which  protects  the  rights  of  beneficiaries,  encourages  the 
soundness  of  pension  funds,  and  promotes  the  stability  of  the  pension  system  and  the 
economy.  The  International  Network  of  Pension  Regulators  and  Supervisors  (INPRS)  was 
established  in  2000  as  a  forum  for  policy  dialogue  and  exchange  of  information  between 
members on regulatory, supervisory, and financial issues, with the aim of promoting (i) the 
development  of  private  pensions  systems  complementary  to  public  systems;  (ii)  the 
development  of  an  adequate  regulatory  structure  and  financial  infrastructure;  and  (iii)  the 
implementation of best practices and principles. Regional networks have been established 
within INPRS. An Asia-Pacific regional network was inaugurated in 2002 to, among other things, 
help organize training and research seminars specific to the region and to exchange study 
groups among countries in the region.   
 
9.  ADB has been an observer member of the Asia-Pacific regional network and has been 
approached about hosting and cosponsoring its next annual regional meeting in 2004. The 
annual  meeting  and  an  associated  conference  on  private  pensions  in  Asia  will  be  jointly 
sponsored  and  organized  by  ADB  and  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development (OECD).  Both events are intended to reinforce the development of INPRS, 
following previous regional meetings in Asia—PRC (2001), the Republic of Korea (2002), and 
India (2003)—and facilitate discussions among regulators of key issues related to the regulation 
and supervision of private pensions in the region. Issues include (i) governance of private 
pension  funds;  (ii)  rights  of  beneficiaries  and  their  education;  (iii)  adequate  investment 
regulations;  (iv)  appropriate  supervisory  structures  and  methods;  (v)  the  management  of 
pension  funds  for  government  workers;  (vi)  the  design  and  distribution  of  pensions  and 
insurance  products  in  emerging  markets;  and  (vii)  financial  risk  management  in  insurance 
companies and pension funds.    
 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output  
 
10.         The TA will help strengthen the capacity of financial sector regulators and supervisors 
in Asia through support for regional training efforts and seminars on key sector issues.  The TA 
is expected to facilitate the incorporation of international best practice approaches to financial 
sector regulation and supervision in training programs at regional and national levels.     
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.         The proposed TA will have three components. 
 
12.       Component A will support a continuation of the APEC FRTI for a further year through the 
development  and  implementation  of  additional  training  courses  for  financial  regulators  and 
supervisors  in  DMCs  and  developed  Asian  APEC  economies  in  line  with  training  priorities 
identified by advisory group members. The component will help complete training curricula and 
materials and build a critical mass of potential trainers in the region.  For banking supervision, 
this will include a new course on risk-focused supervision. In addition, existing courses, such as 
the special training-of-trainers course and courses on market risk analysis and risk management, 
including  operational  risks  related  to  information  technology  and  internal  controls,  will  be 
repeated to increase the number of potential trainers in DMC supervisory agencies.  As much as 
possible, efforts will be made to include case studies that are relevant to the conditions and 
issues  faced  by  supervisors  in  different  types  of  DMCs.  For  securities  regulation,  another

4  
investigation and enforcement course will be implemented, which will use more case studies 
(including from within the region) than earlier courses, in response to feedback received from 
participants. All courses will be open to participants from Asian APEC economies and non-APEC 
DMCs. Training materials and seminar papers will be disseminated through the external ADB 
Finance and APEC FRTI web sites and/or distributed directly to DMC financial supervisory 
authorities  and  regional  training  institutions  such  as  the  South  East  Asian  Central  Banks 
(SEACEN) Research and Training Centre, whose staff will also be invited to join the training 
courses organized under the TA. The TA will further support the management of the FRTI's 
enhanced advisory group structure.   
 
13.  Component B will support the development and implementation of specialized training 
programs for banking, securities, pensions, and insurance regulators and supervisors on the 
incorporation of anti-money laundering concerns in their supervision and enforcement activities.  
Related  training  materials  and  curricula  will  be  disseminated  to  supervisory  agencies  in  all 
DMCs. 
 
14.  Component C will support the next annual seminar of the INPRS regional network and 
the associated conference mainly by funding travel expenses of resource speakers from Asia 
and other costs associated with holding the conference.   
                       
15.  Detailed terms of reference for the TA consultants are given in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000. Foreign exchange costs in the amount of $400,000 
will be financed on a grant basis from ADB's TA funding program. The United States Federal 
Reserve Bank and other APEC regulatory and supervisory agencies will make contributions in 
kind through the provision of instructors and workshop venues and facilities.  OECD would be 
funding resource persons from outside the region. The cost estimates and financing plan of the 
TA are given in Appendixes 3 and 4. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.   ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA.4 
 
18.      The TA will be implemented over a period of 12 months commencing in January 2004.  
The TA will involve a total of about 6 person-months of international consulting services. The 
international consultants, who will have expertise in devising and conducting training on financial 
supervisory issues, will be engaged as individuals in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants. All resource persons financed under the TA will be from ADB member 
countries.  
 
 
 
                                                           
4  The Finance and Infrastructure Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSFI) has 
managed the FRTI on behalf of ADB for the last 2 years.  However, this function might be transferred to the 
Regional Economic Monitoring Unit (REMU), if overall responsibility for acting as ADB’s APEC focal point is shifted 
from RSFI to REMU.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening the Capacity of Financial Sector Regulators and Supervisors, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Financial Sector Supervision Training Expert (estimated input level about 2 person-
months) 
 
1.  The expert will 
 
(i)  manage  the  structure  of  the  advisory  group  of  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic 
Cooperation (APEC) Financial Regulators' Training Initiative (FRTI), which will, 
among  others,  involve  (a)  the  preparation  and  facilitation  of  advisory  group 
meetings;  (b)  the  conduct  and  analysis  of  regular  surveys  on  the  status  of 
national training efforts and emerging training needs; (c) coordination with other 
regional and global training providers; (d) the collection and dissemination of 
information on regional training resources, materials, and events including on the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) external APEC web site; and (e) organizing the 
transfer of  training programs and products developed under the FRTI to training 
institutions at regional and national levels;  
 
(ii)  organize and facilitate one regional training seminar for  securities regulators 
under the FRTI; and 
 
(iii)  prepare progress reports on the FRTI for the APEC finance ministers process. 
 
 
B.  Banking Supervision Training Expert (estimated input level about 1.5 person-months) 
 
2.  The expert will 
 
(i)  organize and facilitate four regional training seminars under the FRTI;  
 
(ii)  develop  training  content,  including  case  studies  that  address  conditions  and 
issues faced by supervisors in different types of developing member countries 
(DMCs) for incorporation in training seminars; and 
 
(iii)  conduct a special train-the-trainers course for banking supervisors. 
 
C.  Anti-Money Laundering Expert(s) (estimated input level about 2.5 person-months) 
 
3.  The expert(s) will 
 
(i)  develop curricula and materials for training courses on the incorporation of anti-
money laundering concerns in financial sector regulation and supervision; 
 
(ii)  prepare,  organize,  and  conduct  two  comprehensive,  in-depth  separate 
specialized regional training seminars for banking supervisors, and securities, 
insurance,  and  pension  regulators  on  all  aspects  of  anti-money  laundering, 
including (a) types of money laundering activities, (b) determination of financial 
sector activities and business areas that are at risk, (c) know-your-customer 
standards, (d) assessment of the adequacy of financial institutions' suspicious 
transactions reporting systems, (e) the role of financial regulators in anti-money

(iii)   participate in panel discussions for seminars, as requested.
